Legal_Issue: Appropriateness of the RAD's application of the reasonableness standard in reviewing RPD decisions
Outcome: Refugee claims dismissed due to lack of credible evidence and existence of internal flight alternative
Credibility_Assessment: RPD and RAD found applicants lacked credibility
Legal_Provision: Section 96 and Section 98 of IRPA regarding standard of review
Basis_of_Claim: Persecution risk in country of origin
Proceeding_Type: Refugee appeal before RAD, followed by judicial review
Application_Error: Improper application of reasonableness standard preventing reweighing of IFA evidence
Evidence_Ignored: Evidence relevant to Internal Flight Alternative
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness vs. palpable and overriding error
Application_Factor: Deference to RPD's credibility and IFA findings
Decision_Outcome: Set aside and remanded for redetermination

Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies between applicant's allegations and country documentation
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to establish credibility and risk of persecution
Credibility_Factor: Plausibility of claim, consistency with country conditions, internal coherence of testimony
Legal_Rule: RAD must respect RPD's credibility findings unless demonstrable error exists
Grounds_for_Claim: Political persecution due to husband's activities
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected due to lack of credible evidence
Legal_Framework: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Federal Court review
Defendant_Response: RAD upheld RPD's adverse credibility finding
Remedy_Requested: Leave and judicial review of RAD decision

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee protection, which was denied by the RPD and upheld by the RAD using a reasonableness standard.
Procedural_Issue: RAD applied a reasonableness standard instead of conducting an independent review
Decision_Outcome: RPD denied refugee status; RAD initially upheld the decision
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; RAD decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Legal challenge to RAD's application of reasonableness standard
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by RAD under correct standard of review
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness vs. correctness debate; court suggests broader interpretation needed
Decision_Rationale: RAD should conduct a more comprehensive review in line with Court jurisprudence

Procedural_Issue: RAD applied incorrect standard of review
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether RAD has authority to apply reasonableness standard
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by RPD and upheld by RAD
Outcome: RAD decision set aside, case remanded
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by RAD using correct standard
Decision_Rationale: RAD is an appellate body and must apply palpable and overriding error or hybrid standard

Victim_Status: Individual at risk due to family wealth and perceived activism
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant credible but denied claim on other grounds

Key_Evidence_Issue: Standard of review applied by RAD
Dispute_Type: Standard of review in refugee appeals
Consequences_of_Action: RAD decision set aside, remanded for redetermination

Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on extortion risk
Legal_Issue: Appropriate standard of review for RAD
Evidence_Assessment: Fear based on family wealth and conflict environment
Decision_Outcome: Claim denied by RPD, upheld by RAD
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate well-founded fear
Legal_Rule: RAD must apply palpable and overriding error standard
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of extortion and forced enlistment in Syria
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached due to procedural error

Dispute_Type: Refugee claim involving nondisclosure of activities
Legal_Issue: Standard of review applied by RAD
Decision_Outcome: Claim rejected by RPD, upheld by RAD
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove eligibility for protection
Legal_Rule: RAD must substitute its decision unless bound by credibility findings
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to perceived activism and fundraising
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided due to procedural error
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside

Application_Facts: The Applicants' refugee claims were dismissed by the RPD and upheld by the RAD, prompting a judicial review.
Procedural_Issue: The RAD erred by applying a reasonableness standard instead of conducting an independent assessment.
Decision_Outcome: RAD decision quashed
Outcome: Judicial review granted, matter referred back to a different RAD panel
Remedy_Sought: Independent reassessment by a different RAD panel
Decision_Rationale: The RAD has equal expertise to the RPD in assessing documentary evidence and must conduct an independent assessment rather than reviewing for reasonableness.

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of citizenship application decision
Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in applying the physical presence test for residency requirements under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Outcome: Minister's judicial review application granted; Citizenship Judge's decision overturned
Evidence_Type: Record of physical presence days in Canada
Legal_Provision: Paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act requiring 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years prior to application
Basis_of_Claim: Respondent was two days short of the required 1,095-day physical presence period
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Physical presence requirement cannot be waived by Citizenship Judge; no discretion to blend tests or deem shortfall insignificant
Application_Error: Improper blending of residency tests and treating a two-day shortfall as insignificant
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to Citizenship Judge's interpretation of residency requirements
Legal_Standard: Statutory compliance with 1,095-day physical presence requirement under s. 5(1)(c)
Application_Factor: Number of days physically present in Canada during the four-year period preceding application
Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside; Respondent may reapply if eligible
Authority: Federal Court (implied from judicial review context)

Application_Facts: Jamil's testimony and documents contained minor discrepancies that were exaggerated by the RPD.

Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Irreparable harm to family and balance of convenience favor applicant; removal officer erred in denying discretion

Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Separation of genuine family unit constitutes irreparable harm; balance of convenience favors applicant

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credible fear but risk not individualized

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear acknowledged but entry non-compliant
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Failure to report does not automatically disqualify, but risk not found to be personalized

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – Board considered all relevant evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Personalized risk versus generalized danger
Crimes.Application_Factor: Individual targeting within context of widespread violence

Legal_Issue: Whether 'LIGHTRECYCLE & DESIGN' is clearly descriptive under s. 12(1)(b) of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: New evidence was considered; court found Registrar's analysis unreasonable due to multiple interpretations of 'light' and lack of justification for prioritizing word over design
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed; trademark remains unregistrable
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant (Product Care Association) to demonstrate registrability
Credibility_Factor: Registrar's reasoning deemed unreasonable by court
Legal_Rule: A trademark is not registrable if it is clearly descriptive of the goods or services (s. 12(1)(b))
Grounds_for_Claim: Trademark 'LIGHTRECYCLE & DESIGN' is clearly descriptive of recycling services for light-related products
Outcome_on_Merits: Trademark not registrable as it is clearly descriptive
Key_Evidence_Considered: Meaning and interpretation of 'light', presence of design element in mark
Defendant_Response: Registrar rejected registration; upheld on appeal with revised reasoning
Remedy_Requested: Registration of 'LIGHTRECYCLE & DESIGN' as a trademark

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on alleged membership in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's permanent residence application was denied due to alleged membership in the Armenian Revolutionary Federation (ARF), which the officer deemed a terrorist organization
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application denied due to inadmissibility finding
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of procedural fairness; reliance on inadequate sources without proper assessment
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Reliance on biased, non-credible, and publicly available Internet sources without corroboration
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Sources lacked credibility; ARF is recognized as a political party and not listed as a terrorist entity by Canada
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Officer concluded applicant was inadmissible under paragraph 34(1)(f)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer erred by relying on insufficient and biased evidence to classify ARF as a terrorist organization

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Answer Truthfully under IRPA
Crimes.Violation_Type: Alleged failure to provide truthful answers regarding ARF involvement
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant provided historical context about ARF instead of directly confirming or denying violent acts; interpreted as non-compliant
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application denied due to alleged untruthful response
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Disagreement with characterization of ARF as terrorist not equivalent to dishonesty
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to distinguish between disagreement and misrepresentation
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of intent to deceive; explanation consistent with good faith
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant acted in good faith; responses were clarifying rather than evasive
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Officer found applicant failed to answer truthfully under section 16
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement to answer truthfully under section 16(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Disagreement with label does not constitute untruthfulness; officer’s interpretation unreasonable

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged membership in an organization engaged in terrorism
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential risk due to association with alleged terrorist group
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Based on outdated and questionable classification of ARF as terrorist
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Historical designation of ARF by certain countries, but current status as legitimate political party
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Past involvement in armed struggle; no current evidence of terrorist activity
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Applicant acknowledged membership in ARF but contested its designation as terrorist
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Low; based on Azerbaijani government statement and Wikipedia
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Use of unreliable, non-official sources without verification
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Sources considered biased and lacking objectivity; contradicted by Canada’s non-listing of ARF
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Lack of corroboration from Canadian or international authorities
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Classification of political organization as terrorist entity
Residency obligation compliance
Crimes.Legal_Issue: When does a determination of non-compliance with residency obligations become final under section 28 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 28
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order upheld; application for judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus on procedural compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Residency records, appeal timelines, immigration documentation

Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Loss of permanent resident status due to failure to meet residency obligations
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Expiry of appeal period leading to finality of determination
Crimes.Application_Error: Initial failure to appeal within prescribed timeframe
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Interpretation of 'final determination' under IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted; court focused on statutory interpretation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Finality of administrative decisions under immigration law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Appeal extension granted but did not invalidate prior deportation order
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed; no question certified for appeal
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Division, Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), Federal Court

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with residency obligations
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 28, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa and failed to meet physical presence requirements
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent resident subject to residency obligations
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable; based on factual absence rather than false statements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Late appeal and subsequent extension granted by IAD
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Validity of deportation order during pending appeal
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Travel records, residency history, appeal filings
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide timely evidence of residency compliance
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central; decision based on documentary evidence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Deportation order valid but suspended pending appeal
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Suspension or cancellation of deportation order
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Finality of determination after appeal period expires
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Determination becomes final upon expiry of appeal period; extension suspends but does not invalidate removal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with residency obligation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Committing certain offences leading to deportation

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged finality of determination due to pending appeal

Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 46(1)(b), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crime_Name: Discrimination complaint under the Canadian Human Rights Act
Dispute_Type: Human rights discrimination complaint regarding timeliness and discretionary extension
Legal_Issue: Whether the Commission erred in finding the complaint time-barred and failed to exercise discretion for an extension
Evidence_Assessment: Timing of key decisions and communications, including CIC's final decision in June 2004 and a letter from July 2003
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision set aside; matter remitted for reconsideration
Burden_of_Proof: On the Applicant to justify delay and request for extension
Legal_Rule: Complaints must be filed within one year unless an extension is granted by the Commission
Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation that limitation period began in June 2004; challenge to Commission's procedural fairness and reasoning
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case remitted for reconsideration
Key_Evidence_Considered: July 2003 letter as point of crystallization, December 2001 event cited by Respondent, June 2004 CIC decision
Legal_Framework: Canadian Human Rights Act, administrative law principles on discretion and procedural fairness
Defendant_Response: Argued that limitation period began in December 2001
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of Commission's decision, remittal for reconsideration
Legal_Provision: Paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Violation_Type: Failure to assess credible evidence of changed country conditions
Legal_Provision_Violated: Principles of procedural fairness in refugee determination
Governing_Law: Principles of administrative law including res judicata and duty to reconsider based on new evidence
Application_Facts: Applicants are Sri Lankan Tamils claiming persecution based on race and political opinion; mother has a disability; daughter's age is a factor; claim based on deteriorating conditions in Sri Lanka
Claimant_Status: Sri Lankan Tamil refugees, previously rejected, making a subsequent claim
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to properly analyze new evidence linking personal circumstances to changed country conditions
Erroneous reliance on res judicata without full assessment
Evidence_Used: Evidence of deteriorating conditions in Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board did not assess credible evidence connecting applicants’ personal circumstances to changed country conditions
Decision_Outcome: Original refugee claim dismissed by Board based on res judicata
Outcome: Case remanded for redetermination by a different panel
Relief_Sought: Reassessment of claim based on new evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Requirement of significant changes in country conditions
Decision_Rationale: Res judicata applies unless there are significant changes in country conditions or personal circumstances that affect risk; Board must meaningfully assess new evidence
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Legal_Provision_Violated: Citizenship Act - 1095 days of residence in Canada over four years
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 1055 days of presence, 40 days short of required 1095 days
Procedural_Issue: Use of ambiguous 'ongoing presence' language by judge, but not found to be prejudicial
Evidence_Used: Passport records, applicant's testimony, residency documentation
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Missing passport, conflicting evidence on residency days
Credibility_Assessment: Judge questioned the reliability and completeness of applicant's evidence
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Outcome: Residency requirement not satisfied; citizenship application denied
Remedy_Sought: Grant of citizenship or remand for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence or normally resident test under Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: Judge's interpretation was reasonable; evidence was inconclusive and insufficient to prove 1095 days of residency

Legal_Provision_Violated: Rule 30 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: Hasan, a young male Palestinian, applied for refugee status based on systemic risks faced by individuals similarly situated; submitted a Disclosure Package with relevant evidence that was excluded
Procedural_Issue: Exclusion of late-submitted but relevant evidence without proper discretion under Rule 30
Failure to provide adequate reasons for evidence exclusion
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Disclosure Package containing critical evidence was improperly excluded
Lack of consideration of country condition evidence regarding treatment of young male Palestinians
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by initial Board panel
Remedy_Sought: Remittal of the case to a new Board panel for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Definition of Convention Refugee including well-founded fear of persecution
Systemic or broadly based abuse as basis for persecution
Discretion to admit late evidence under Rule 30
Decision_Rationale: The Board erred by narrowly focusing on personal persecution rather than systemic risks to young male Palestinians; failed to exercise discretion under Rule 30 to admit non-prejudicial late evidence
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is Albania capable of protecting the applicants, victims of a blood feud, thus negating their refugee claim?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; RPD decision set aside and case remanded for reconsideration by a different panel.
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee claim based on fear of blood feud and lack of state protection in Albania
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: RPD's failure to consider contradictory evidence regarding Albania's protective capacity
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to reasonably assess state protection availability
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective unreasonableness in access to state protection
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of RPD’s conclusion under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Ability to access state protection in country of origin

Crimes.Crime_Name: Criminal Code Offence relating to Blood Feuds
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm due to ongoing blood feud
Crimes.Threat_Source: Members of opposing family involved in blood feud
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to establish risk, but not adequately considered
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants found credible
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Homicide arising from familial conflict/blood feud
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – resulted in death and ongoing retaliation risk
Crimes.Risk_Type: Retaliatory homicide within blood feud context
Crimes.Targeted_Individual: Murati family as targets of retaliation
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of incident and consequences
Evidence_Type: Contextual reports on blood feuds in Albania
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' account accepted as truthful
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.24
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's status expired on December 31, 2009; claimed preservation under IRPR s.183(5), which did not apply post-2009
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to leave Canada as directed
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Conviction record, immigration file, departure instructions
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer correctly identified inadmissibility due to criminal conviction and overstaying; reasons were brief but sufficient

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Criminal inadmissibility and TRP refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer made errors in refusing TRP due to impaired driving conviction
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA s.24, risk vs. need assessment for TRP
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction for impaired driving, failure to depart Canada
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to justify TRP issuance
Crimes.Legal_Rule: TRPs may be granted under exceptional circumstances at officer’s discretion
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged factual or legal errors in TRP refusal
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Criminal conviction, immigration history, non-compliance with departure directive
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and IRPR provisions on inadmissibility and TRPs
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant challenged refusal via judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official records, conviction documents, immigration file
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial intervention to overturn TRP refusal

Application_Facts: Applicant faced alleged threats from Sri Lankan authorities and Karuna group
Evidence_Used: Threats by Sri Lankan authorities and Karuna group
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Generalized risks rather than Convention grounds, inconsistent evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues found by the Board
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities, more than a mere possibility of persecution or torture
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was reasonable based on credibility concerns and lack of evidence linking threats to Convention grounds

Legal_Issue: Whether the defendant's Skyplume apparatus infringes claims 1 and 2 of the '163 patent
Evidence_Assessment: Expert evidence was used to assess differences in nozzle bifurcation, diffuser presence, and orientation
Decision_Outcome: Defendant's product does not infringe the '163 patent; patent is valid
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff bore the burden of proving infringement
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimony was considered credible and influential
Legal_Rule: Infringement occurs when all essential elements of a patent claim are reproduced
Standard_of_Review: Objective technical and legal comparison of patent claims
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unauthorized reproduction of patented invention
Key_Evidence_Considered: Design differences in nozzle, diffuser, and orientation; commercial success of the patent
Legal_Framework: Patent Act (Canada); principles of novelty, utility, non-obviousness
Defendant_Response: Denied infringement and counterclaimed for invalidity and unfair trade practices
Evidence_Type: Technical expert reports, product design documentation
Outcome: Plaintiff's claim dismissed; costs awarded to defendant
Authority: Canadian court with jurisdiction over intellectual property matters
